<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_panic_std:
```c
_MHD_NORETURN static void
mhd_panic_std (void *cls,
               const char *file,
               unsigned int line,
               const char *reason)
{
  (void) cls; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  fprintf (stderr,
           _ ("Fatal error in GNU libmicrohttpd %s:%u: %s\n"),
           file,
           line,
           reason);
#else  /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  (void) file;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) line;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) reason; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif
  abort ();
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
_MHD_NORETURN static void
mhd_panic_std (void *cls,
               const char *file,
               unsigned int line,
               const char *reason)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 1.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The identifier _MHD_NORETURN is a macro that is commonly defined to expand to a compiler-specific noreturn attribute (for example: __attribute__((noreturn)) on GCC/Clang). If _MHD_NORETURN expands to such an implementation-specific attribute (explicitly documented as a compiler extension), this is a violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 because a language/compiler extension is being used. (If, instead, _MHD_NORETURN expands to the standard C11 keyword _Noreturn or no extension is used, then there is no Rule 1.2 violation.)
